review_title: Excellent benefits, some great departments and people, can be sluggish and hierarchical.
pros: I like the academic atmosphere, hours and benefits, paid time-off, etc. Being part of the inner-workings of a world famous institution is sort of fun. Lots of opportunities for training within the University (computer classes, discounted extension courses, etc.).
cons: Depending which office or school you work for, the culture can be stuffy, sluggish, overly hierarchical, bureaucratic, tough to get ahead or move around, get things done, etc. Parking is tough for car commuters.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Boston, MA
pros: Good exit options from PhD, with active on campus recruiting.  Pay higher than other schools and people are looked out for by the GSAS.
cons: Mentorship tends to be poor.  Expectations are continuously very high.  People are generally unhappy.  Administration is bloated, and overall the place is very bureaucratic.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros:
-Supportive mentor who is at the top of her field
-Many seminars and workshops for career development and to keep up to date to the latest research
-Provide free lunch at seminars to encourage people to attend
-Easy access to the best equipment and reagents
-Socializing is encouraged through beer hours and parties
-Subsidized/free taxi rides for those working at late hours
cons:
-Too many different projects going on so there is no time to go to the seminars and workshops mentioned above
-Sometimes relationships with other co-workers become intense and competitive
-Low salary

review_title: Fantastic place to work and do research - though it may depend slightly on what you are with.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: Weekly happy hours!; very collegial atmosphere; specifically, my PI was a wonderful, caring, and reasonable person to work for and I was very satisfied with the way I was treated.
cons: It is worth noting that one's working experience at HMS may be influenced by the PI you specifically work for. I consider myself very fortunate with the PI I worked with, though I did occasionally hear from others some dissatisfaction with theirs.

review_title: Extremely directed and intense but enjoyable and rewarding
pros: At Harvard, you will be surrounded by intellectuals who share similar goals. Competition is not in the culture but rather is more internal and personal because of the rigorous academic setting. The setting is motivating, not intimidating.
cons: The compensation is very bureaucratic and takes a nearly unacceptable amount of time to issue reimbursement. It is a minimal but annoying con.

review_title: It is an eyeopener to work at Harvard. It consistently manages to hire the very best.
pros: Get to see some of the most talented people at work. It sometimes inspires you to keep up with everyone around you.
cons: Get to see some of the most talented people at work. It sometimes leads to performance anxiety when comparing with the people around you.

pros: Work with fascinating scholars researching cutting edge topics that cross many disciplines at the Graduate School of Design.  The school's resources (especially libraries) are unparalleled.
cons: Student research positions are limited in hours (part time) and usually do not extend beyond graduation.  There are no benefits (health insurance, 401k etc)

pros: As an economics grad student, I have a lot of freedom to work on whatever I find most interesting. I have learned a lot from classes, seminars, and talking to others in my department.
cons: The economics department is very focused on getting students into prestigious academic positions. Students with other goals, like doing policy-relevant research or working in industry, may feel neglected.

review_title: Great benefits and access to world class resources
pros: Great benefits and access to world class resources. Working with leading experts on international issues. Tuistion assistance at Harvard Extension School is another huge benefit.
cons: Personally, the research was interesting but after a while became slow moving. If you enjoy a wide range of issues this may not be the place for you as the work tends to be specialized.

review_title: Great place to work, but some jerks present
pros: Some astonishingly great, high energy, motivated people who usually call it the way they see it; really good locations, interesting work. Benefits are very good.
cons: Have worked for or with a couple of people who really shouldn't be here. Sometimes the place makes hiring mistakes and can take forever to rectify them.

pros:
Great supervisors and direct reports -- very appreciative of my skills and labor
Student interaction was favorable and students, for the most part, also appreciative
Work was interesting and I enjoyed it
cons:
Despite my rare interactions with students and other staff - I wasn't allowed to work remotely
Working from "home" reserved for upper management
Senior Management seemed to favor HU Grads for promotion or advancement
Pay rates painstakingly slow

pros: Vacation, benefits, some decent people amidst the bullies and harassers
cons: Unbeknownst to me, I joined a department where the man in charge had already been reported to HR by 3 women. I found this out when I became the 4th woman to report him. What happened next? HR and Title IX sided with him, he's still in his cozy corner office in University Hall, and I lost my job. All of this happened with the blessing of the so-called leadership at the College. And I thought I was doing the right thing by reporting this creep. LOL!

pros: An amazing place to work if you want to spend your days with very smart and highly engaged fellow employees. You will meet some amazing individuals.
cons: While individual units are well run there is   poor leadership and vision coming from the top as to how  to compete in the future

review_title: Not a place to start a career without a pHD
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: great people to work with, academic environment with lots of opportunities to learn, see talks presented by experts in their fields, etc.
cons: Unless you are a student, or a post-doc, there are no research jobs with upward mobility.  If you are not attending school there, you will be on career "pause" as long as you are there.

review_title: Probably one of the best places to do postdoc, but think twice before continuing with postdoc fellowship
pros: Most Harvard postdocs are smart people, thus it creates engaging environment. The funding situation varies between labs, but most labs are usually in good funding situation.
cons:
Too much competition, lack of mentoring, some indifferent colleagues, uncertain future.
Low pay, which is typical of postdoc positions. We're told that we are sacrificing for the future. Still, 40K after 4-6 years of training (graduate) doesn't justify that. High cost of living in Boston area doesn't help.

review_title: The RA program at HBS is a great short-term choice for post-undergrad or -grad.
pros: Incredibly interesting work; invaluable mentorship from leading professors in the academic business field; great perks and development programs that you would expect from a leading business school.
cons: Depending on your boss, you may need to set limits in terms of work-life balance. While the pay isn't incredibly exciting, it's more than fair for research work the benefits are incredible. The RA program is limited to 5 years, maximum, so you don't get opportunities for advancement.

review_title: Mixed - day to day experience often a function of immediate work group which can change a lot
pros: Interesting people, vibrant setting, anything is possible
cons: It really depends on the immediate working group - some are incredible, some less so. While anything is possible, getting things done can be like pulling teeth because it sometimes feels like everyone has to have or wants to have an opinion even when they don't really need to; this can be tiresome. There are sometimes trust issues, 2nd guessing etc....

pros: Good job overall with a pretty decent salary.  Work hours non-specified which is as much a pro as a con, up to you to decide how much to work.
cons: Work hours non-specified and weekly wage non guaranteed.  Can be seen as a benefit but it would be nice to have more assurance as to weekly wages.

review_title: An engaging and rewarding community environment
pros: Many personal opportunities within the University environment if one wants to pursue more than their current working position as in evening classes, seminars and courses.  All the best benefits for pension, healthcare, vac/sick/time.  Many schools and departments to choose from for best fit.  Library privileges are the extra bonus.
cons: Not very good at promotion from within, and mostly lateral moves.  HR as is the case most places these days can be a minefield of personalities not conducive for honest help.

pros: Amazingly beautiful location and facility, excellent benefits, good job security. If you have an interest in the humanities, you have access to a great deal of resources.
cons: Leadership is not transparent and place is plagued by politics. Toxic people are allowed to remain in place with no accountability. A lot of back-stabbing.

review_title: Great place to work, but very ossified hierarchy"
pros: I worked in Technical Services for the Library System (buying books, essentially): Wonderful lifestyle, great place to be, nice benefits. I'm happy to have started my career there, but it's not an atmosphere that is easy to rise up in or gain more management experience.
cons: The pay was low. Granted I was working in a Humanties field within academia, but a lot of pressure from changes in the education business really put the squeeze on headcount, overall job-enjoyability, etc.

pros: Harvard offers tremendous benefits, from vacation time, medical benefits and financial investments.   They offer various job opportunities and often promote  from within the university.  They believe in a family and work life balance.  I feel fortunate to work at this university.
cons: I can't  think of any cons.

pros: Fantastic resources, outstanding libraries. An atmosphere that prides itself on supporting fellows to produces gold-standard research. You are surrounded my passionate and interesting people and there are so many fantastic lectures and events to attend.
cons: I really struggles to think of anything. This might be the best place to undertake research, it is fully equip to deal with any research need.

review_title: Changing the world for the better
job_title: Regional Director, Alumni Affairs and Development in Cambridge, MA
pros: Smart, creative, hardworking colleagues. Exciting, dynamic environment. Great benefits. Great neighborhood (Harvard Square). Strong sense of community. Important mission. Lots of opportunities for career growth. Great professional development offerings.  Exciting research and scholarship. Wonderful new President (Larry Bacow).
cons:
(This review is re: the development office)
Surprisingly, even Harvard doesn’t always hit the nail on the head vis a vis hiring — specifically in the development shop’s  upper management. They are making some corrections now, and that is encouraging. Salaries are modest.

review_title: A place where one can contribute at many levels in the public health space.
pros: Harvard values professional growth and will allow folks with a starting skill set to achieve and learn more.  There is great opportunity for paid continuing education.
cons: Harvard has a strong culture that is not always entrepreneurial. " Every boat on its own bottom" philosophy often gets in the way of cooperation.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Cambridge, MA
pros: Harvard is a great place to work.  Superior benefits, supportive work environment and many opportunities for cultural enrichment on campus!
cons: There really are not any cons here except for low salaries.  There is ample opportunity to move around if the current position is not quite the right fit.

pros: Amazing benefits and endless educational opportunities (if you make the time for them)
cons: Nealy impossible to move laterally within organization, which is structured for the benefit of high-status faculty and administration.  Salaries for supporting research staff seems under-appreciative of immense "trickle down" workload and there is virtually no staff support for mid-level employees.

pros: This one of the top places in the world to do research. You can meet amazing people, talented and very smart.
cons: Competition is fierce. Sometimes you find out about people's behaviors that go beyond healthy competition and just make you question if this represents how science is done nowadays.

review_title: Great Place, wish work culture was better
job_title: Staff Assistant III in Cambridge, MA
pros: Great  benefits, University has excellent resources, interesting and educated colleagues
cons: Corporate culture (in the negative) has infiltrated in the last several years, it is noticeably different from when I started 14 years ago, very little upward mobility, Many long-time employees jumped ship when I was there working for the libraries.

review_title: Harvard treats Grad Students (in science) well
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Cambridge, MA
pros: Harvard takes good care of its graduate students (at least those in the hard sciences). Stipends are reasonable, and they have been quite receptive to graduate student input (although at the threat of unionization).
cons: Rent is very expensive in the area, and it is hard to afford a place very close to classes or your research building.

pros:
There are 11 schools and numerous museums and libraries to work in.  Each school has it's own distinct community and atmosphere.  Some are more formal, whereas others are more relaxed. 
The benefits (health care, transportation subsidies, retirement) are substantial and excellent.
There are some lovely people working there.
cons:
Salaries are lower than private businesses.
Training and oversight of managers is uneven to nonexistent in some parts of the university.

pros: A very decent place for an independent] minded, creative types who are looking for  day jobs. Benefits are humane and access to library and classes and wonderful.
cons: Yikes FAS.The mgt has nearly zero business acumen, and are often zombie-like to the vertical, hierarchy/medieval university type power system (which we all know in the 21st century is bunk). Fascinating to observe, painful to experience day by day.

review_title: Exciting but no hope for career advancement from the inside
pros: Lots of really smart people to interact with on a daily basis.  Obtaining experience at Harvard is excellent for career prospects almost anywhere.
cons: There is no hope of getting a permanent job at Harvard and one has to look outside for further career advancement.

pros: As an RA at HBS I worked with incredible faculty as well as leaders in organizations around the world. I traveled to various countries to conduct field research and wrote HBS case studies as well as a book with my professor. The hours were really great and the travel was amazing.
cons: My experience was unusual - most RA's never or rarely travel. It's also so dependent on which faculty member you are working with.

review_title: Great place to study, live and meet other like minded young people. Also a good place to meet great mentors
pros: Cutting edge technology and a vibrant city full of ambitious young people. Very challenging research and educational experience to stimulate your inner curiosity. Certainly a place to be for a solid career foundation.
cons: Very competitive environment and sometimes it is hard to cope with the pace of studying and working. The weather obviously is a major blow if you hate snow.

review_title: Strong training if you are self-motivated.
pros: In my program, the university attracts the top students in the field.  Being a graduate student in the department exposes you to cutting-edge research in important fields.
cons: It can be difficult to get professors to interact with you, so you need to be self-motivated.  The physical facilities are not wel maintained.

pros: Great knowledge base. Opportunities to further career beyond most obvious path. Many mentors who encourage the personal and professional development of entry level position researchers.
cons: Compensation. Cambridge is an expensive city. Mid-management sometimes not the best fit for the job. Quite a bit of bureaucracy, but I guess it is a given for a large university. Very hard to advance to senior level, being here is no guarantee of getting tenure.

review_title: Great place to do cutting edge research, O.K. place to work.
pros:
Cutting edge research
Wonderful community of peers and private investigators
International reputation
Limitless supply of researchers and collaborators that make research a lot easier to perform
cons:
An overall cut-throat environment with high expectations and even higher levels of competition.
A poorly defined path for promotion
Poorly defined mentoring program for junior faculty.

pros: Great networking and resources available across Harvard community and throughout Boston. Amazing programming across all the campuses, and easy access to all of it. Wonderful community.
cons: Very intense, high-competition environment. Not much attention paid to training/mentorship. Sometimes the wealth of resources makes it difficult to sift through and find what you actually need.

review_title: If work-life is your priority, Harvard is great.  If you want to live above poverty, it is not.
pros: For a healthy work-life balance, Harvard is the place.  Harvard offers terrific benefits and opportunities to study to its employees.  Flex time and near free gym membership are other perks.
cons: The hulking bureaucracy slows everything down.  Career employees are unmotivated.  Salary is low.  There is not a well developed incentive structure.

review_title: Very stressful, but very much worth it if that's what you want in life
pros: Good connection in the academic world, higher salary than same position in other universities (as far as I know), flexible vacation time
cons: Stressful - unless you are super good at managing your time and are a genius, you will need to work on weekends and evenings, sometimes also holidays and vacations.

pros: Fair salary, fantastic benefits and perks (I loved having access to HUHS, Harvard's own hospital system and the health and wellness classes).  Vibrant academic culture, interesting people, and plenty of opportunity for career growth...professional development classes, huge discounts for courses at Harvard Extension, etc.
cons: The administrative offices can be heavily bureaucratized and poorly run; mediocrity, sloppiness, and rudeness seem to be accepted in some departments.  I found some of them very frustrating to work with.

pros: Excellent colleagues, great direct manager who is interested in my professional development, advancement, etc. The staff culture is very positive, and we've developed a very friendly, supportive system.
cons: There is a cultural problem in that students perceive faculty to have administrative authority, when in fact, administrative staff are the ones truly responsible for making things work. Unfortunately, this misunderstanding on the part of the student sometimes makes it difficult for staff to do their jobs.

pros: Harvard has decent benefits, 403b matching, and generous time off.  Work/life balance is generally good, our school recently starting allowing work from home.  Opportunity to work with talented faculty and students.
cons: The high turnover in my department and the slow hiring practices of HR mean that your workload is often difficult to manage

review_title: 9 months here so far, and no plans to leave anytime soon
job_title: Staff Assistant III in Cambridge, MA
pros: Really good benefits, supportive coworkers (at least in my office), lots of resources and professional development opportunities available
cons: Really large organization means sometimes it can take a really long time to get things fixed, and there's a lot of one office does things this way and another office does things this way so the learning curve can be a little difficult at the start.

pros: great benefits, good salary, great career development opportunities, very prestigious place to work in a very nice city, opportunity to meet and work in a very diverse multicultural environment
cons: very competitive environment, may not get as much support as promised in the beginning, workplace politics may be an issue

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: You are surrounded by motivated and high-achieving researchers; both yourself and your work receive extra recognition merely because of your affiliation; you are continually exposed to opportunities to grow your network and career, both through colleagues at the university and through people met at social functions - it's a happening city.
cons: Poor monetary compensation when compared with other universities internationally; frustratingly lethargic administration - even by university standards (particularly finance and IT); complex organisational hierarchy.

job_title: Mathematics Course Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: The opportunity to help teach a math course really helps you gain a deeper understanding of the course material and serves to improve your technical communication skills. You also get to interact with incredible students and wonderful professors, which is a great plus.
cons: A substantial portion of a course assistant's workload consists of holding review sessions and grading exams, so the time commitment is heaviest when you need time to study for your own exams.

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros: Work with the best minds of the world, plus interaction with leaders and opportunities to learn. Flexible hours and mindset in productivity rather than time at work. Best benefit package and amazing cafeteria. One of best environment for collaborative and team work as well as individual work.
cons: Compensation for non-faculty researcher are lower versus private sector as any place in academic setting. Pressure to get extra-mural funding increases the overall level of stress.

review_title: Stimulating work in an abusive environment
pros: The students are incredibly gifted and the work is stimulating
cons: The people I worked for and with were extremely abusive. It was a very difficult place to work and the pay was terrible. There were no benefits at all, no time off, and the hours were very long.

pros: Great experience in learning and dealing with students if you are thinking of getting into teaching at some point in your career. Very smart student body which will be an additional learning experience from a student TA perspective
cons: Head professor throws work on you, asks you to lead students without actually leading or giving formal and directive feedback, industry standard pay for a TA, however a cap of 10hrs/week of pay even though working above 20

review_title: Good benefits, mediocre pay and work environment
pros: Benefits are comprehensive and include a variety of items not found elsewhere.  Generous tuition assistance plan, numerous health benefit options, fitness benefit, etc.  35-hour full-time workweek for staff.
cons: Bureaucracy is everywhere.  Most staff positions fall under the CTW Union, so pay raises, work schedules, etc. are fixed and non-negotiable.   Pay rate is based on 35-hour workweek, so take-home pay is less than comparable positions with 40-hour workweeks.

review_title: Lack of diversity, career development opportunities
pros: Amazing paid time off, tuition reimbursement, OK health benefits, matching 403b, HLS has some good social events for employees, union representation at many job grades
cons: Poor management skills (academics are terrible people/organization managers), lack of transparency, decision by committee, slow to change, low pay, almost complete lack of career mobility - you must leave and come back to move up

job_title: Web Project Manager in Cambridge, MA
pros: Outstanding benefits at Harvard, consistent across Harvard
cons:
Salaries may be lower at Harvard compared to the business sector
Supervision varies depending on who you work for.  Many are type-A with high expectations
Encouragement on professional development varies depending on supervisor
Difficult to break into working at Harvard. Try to network to make inroads.
No set career paths; you are on your own and salary may go down if you move to a different job

review_title: It All Depends on Your Faculty Chair
pros: Great energy being in Harvard Square. Access to amazing resources. Opportunity for continuous learning.
cons: If your program is overseen by a faculty chair, as most are at Harvard, your experience will depend on the personality and management style of the chair. Mine would speak disrespectfully to staff constantly. Expectations and goal posts changed regularly. Goals were established without sufficient resources to achieve them. Staff turned over constantly.

job_title: Human Resources Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Harvard is one of the few employers I have experienced that really cares about employees.  Benefits are great, pay is always being analyzed, and it is truly mission-based.  If I hadn't moved away I would probably have spent my whole career there.
cons:
Different schools don't always communicate well.
Pay is lower than private sector.
Some issues with faculty and student egos.

review_title: You're lucky to be employed here
pros: Excellent salary, excellent benefits. There is a lot of prestige to working here, especially to people who know little beyond the name. Launches you very well for your next job somewhere else.
cons: Administration doesn't care about you and treats you as if you are the least important thing at the University. You are totally replaceable no matter who you are and they let you know it at every opportunity.

pros: Working with very dedicated and motivated people. Very good benefits. Opportunity for taking classes for free.
cons: These are only cautions not really cons. It is a very demanding environment. It is typical for an institute at that level. A research assistant may need to work extra hours on many days to keep a good progress.

review_title: teaching fellow for harvard extension school
pros: well paid and less work. 20 hours/week. i teach weekly section and office hour. there are 4 teaching fellows in a section of 80 student. all of the other teaching fellows have taken this course so it is very easy to manage them
cons: the tuition is not waived for this position, so the salary cannot cover everything and i still need financial aid from somewhere else

pros: Co-workers were nice - some of the managers were good.  Pay was very competitive and good benefits.
cons: Very low workload, emphasized in interview what a challenging and interesting job it would be but it was not.  Almost everyone there was much older and things moved very slowly.

pros: Harvard University have a wide array of great benefits such as retirement plan and subsidized education at several Harvard coursed. In most of cases you either pay around 60.00 for tuition or 10% of course. Also, Harvard offer a very good health plan and some money that you can use towards gym membership in addition to a steeped subsidized gym at Harvard campus.
cons: The major con at Harvard is the bureaucracy.

pros: Collaborate with world class researchers; access to a wide range of scholarly papers and conferences; excellent funding for students; excellent mentorship.
cons: Moderate to poor focus on teaching; large and inflexible administration; some research ifocus is important in a practical sense, but sometimes short-sighted or not cutting-edge.

pros: lots of opportunities for professional development, tons of educational opportunities, highly educated co-workers, lots of resources available, kind of like a small city.
cons: Very decentralized, one hand doesn't know what the other is doing, very political, lots of professors with big egos managing staff poorly, extremely bureaucratic which can limit your ability to try new ideas.

review_title: The group I work for is AMAZING, SEAS Administration...not so good.
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Cambridge, MA
pros: GREAT benefits including $40 classes at Harvard Extension school, taught by Harvard and MIT professors. Top pay for administration plus generous contributions to IRAs. Classes offered for professional advancement.
cons: The higher up the ladder you go the more difficult the people are to work with (this experience only applies to the SEAS division).

pros: The hours for this job have been amazing. I can work as many or as few hours per week as I'd like for most of the year.
cons: The pay isn't very appealing. But, then again, one cannot expect to be pair a great deal to do research without a PhD.

review_title: Great place to work with smart people
pros:
Amazing benefits
Smart people who care about what they're doing
Cambridge is fantastic
Strong union support for many employees ensures better benefits for all (non-union too)
Discounts for events around Harvard, Boston, and even nationally
cons:
Not that much as far as downsides
Could maybe streamline the application and HR appointment process

job_title: Senior Grants Manager, Immunology & Infectious Diseases in Boston, MA
pros: Great benefits. Recent focus towards work/life balance.
cons: Unqualified people placed in management positions simply because they have been there a long time. Although the university has increased its focus on flexible schedules and work/life balance, implementation is left up to the individual departments and management is nopt willing to change or be flexible.

pros: Great resources to do research, and decent stipend and health insurance as a science graduate student in GSAS. Many great classes available.
cons: The environment is very competitive, publishing is the most important thing to most professors rather than mentorship. Most labs are either big labs where you will not have a lot of attention, or small labs with micromanaging professors who are trying to get tenure. Choose your mentors wisely.

review_title: Great work environment, strong benefits package.
pros: Leading research university, with many opportunities to learn and work with leaders in every field. Excellent benefits including subsidized or free classes at the extension school and elsewhere in the University. Especially useful in improving skills either for career or academic development. I loved working there and the people were always interesting to talk to and easy to work with.
cons: Large organization, with sometimes cumbersome bureaucratic bottlenecks.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Vibrant community, smart and motivated people, great brand name, good experience if you want to stay in academia, very very low pay...
cons: Someone with 3 scientific degrees usually earns about one half to one third of the amount someone with an undergraduate degree makes in industry or other fields like finance. This wouldn't be an issue if the absolute value was still reasonable. It isn't.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: Beautiful campus, great staff, really amazing place to work.  Looks outstanding on a resume, both in academia and industry.
cons: Low pay relative to industry, and even compared to some other academic jobs.

review_title: Good intentions but could do more.
pros: Great benefits and competitive pay to start. Health benefits are great but there are many differences between what the Union and non-Union employees are offered.
cons: Difficult to access benefits. There are a number of things that appear to be an option but are really out of reach. Salary does not keep up with experience. Management makes progress difficult.

pros: Excellent health, dental, vacation benefits, plus cool perks like free flowers in the spring and ability to take classes for $40 at the Extension School.
cons: Although there is plenty of opportunities to move around, moving up within a department can be hard if you are are in the union (I think it's based on seniority rather than merit and past experience).

review_title: The Best Place I Have Ever Worked
pros: Great Benefits, People are Dedicated and Brilliant in Research Roles, Always Something Very Interesting Going on and to Learn
cons: If you don't have a PHD, your career options in Research will be limited, it is best to in the long run pursue more applied analysis in government work or nonprofit work, though this is not unique to Harvard, it is like this for all research.

review_title: It's a great place for faculty and no one else
pros: Prestige, prestige, prestige, location (if you like winter), lots of intelligent people, lots of great talks and dinners, and the students, undergraduates and gradutes, are wonderful.
cons: Terrible management, terrible decision-making, terrible money management, completely demoralizing, people are unappreciated, work very, very hard with no recognition, all are treated poorly except faculty. The place is saturated with arrogant people who have little compassion for non-tenured people.

pros: Great people. Great name. Convenient way for a student to make some money while attending. Some jobs are better than others.
cons: There are no long term benefits to working as a student (no health or general benefits), and there are few opportunities for growth in my opinion.

review_title: Great place to be a graduate student
pros: One thing that sets Harvard apart is that world renowned scientists, politicians, and leaders come to campus to give talks all the time! The culture in each lab varies a lot and changes as graduate students and postdocs come and go.
cons: The professors travel a lot and are really, really busy with teaching and other obligations. I hope my next boss is more available.

review_title: Great Part Time Job for Students
job_title: Fung Library Circulation Desk in Cambridge, MA
pros: There is not much foot traffic so there is not much "work" to do, which leaves plenty of time for studying. It is a great part time job.
cons: The questions you get can be very specific and often will never be asked again. Pay is less than some other on campus jobs, but you also can't do homework at most of them.

pros: I got to work at Harvard University as a Student Computer Technician and help people with their IT problems and other technical issues.
cons: There are no cons that readily come to my mind, but I will try to think of some and update as they come to me.

pros: Great work life balance and paid time off. Excellent Benefits
cons: Can never take advantage of the vacation and perks because employees are overworked

pros: Access to all that Harvard has to offer including the many interesting talks that happen on campus, the people working on all sorts of projects, great lab equipment, and lots of opportunities that come your way for sampling being attached to the university.
cons: You're still a postdoc completely at the whim of your professor with a postdoc salary in one of the most expensive cities in the US.

review_title: Going through big changes, not excited about the future.
pros:
Probably the best benefits of any organization in the United States other than the big tech companies. Tons of time off, the health plan is good, and the free classes at Extension are worth taking (and usually cost around $2,500). I'm not sure how long these benefits will last!

The work/life balance seems okay, though I'd imagine this is dependent on which part of the school you are in. People you directly work with will likely be friendly.

You get to say "I work at a little school outside Boston, you may have heard of it..."
cons:
I'm not sure if this is a result of the new president, some MBA consulting firm (this is my guess), or what, but there has been a noticeable shift in the attitude towards lower level workers/labor at Harvard. There is a massive centralization campaign going on right now across all schools, bringing all the staff further under the umbrella of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. With this change, there has been upheaval in how things are managed. Non-union members haven't gotten a raise in 2 years that exceeds inflation (join a union folks), and we were told this is because the endowment hasn't performed well. Raises are tied directly to how well the endowment performs, and are only tangentially related to performance. In most cases (I'm sure there are exceptions) working harder or smarter will not result in better pay. Many administrative positions are being cut and outsourced to 3rd party vendors. When people leave, their positions are not filled, and the work falls on those left behind. Communication surrounding these issues is extremely poor. Major decisions that will directly impact your work will be decided by 2 or 3 people at the top, and they'll forget to tell you. My guess is they will continue to squeeze workers in order to cut costs. Within my unit, it feels like it's reaching a breaking point.

This is one of the most highly political environments I've ever worked in. Prepare to ingratiate yourself to whoever is at the top of the chain in order to advance your career. Doing good work is not going to cut it.

I have only seen the tip of the iceberg when it comes to graft and waste, and it is mind boggling. If you get into a place where you can see some of these budgets, your head will spin. The people at the very top use their budgets to pay their friends $$$$$$$$ to do make-work. I believe this is called "networking".

Borderline, there is no culture. Our "retreats" have been things like going to a classroom, and doing a Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats chart to figure out how to be more efficient workers. 

Overall, I'm surprised not to see any of these complaints more prominently in the newer reviews given the discussions I've seen internally. Perhaps that will change!

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: Harvard University Health Services - overall a great place to work - patient population, co-workers, team spirit, benefits.
cons: Harvard University Health Services - top heavy, middle management, physicians do not have a big voice in making structural changes to benefit patient care.  Organization appears to be downsizing and cutting patient resources.

review_title: Working at Harvard is not what you think it is...
pros: Status and recognition from outsiders
cons: A significant proportion of the resources are expended in keeping Harvard's image pristine. There is very little freedom of expression, and fostering creativity among staff is very low. A culture of fear reigns behind the Potemkin Village facade of Harvard's image.

pros: The ability to do a variety of tasks as well as work with some interesting projects and exposure to new technology.
cons: Hard to say, people were very nice , friendly, helpful,etc.  Probably the politics and the changes in senior management made people a little scared.

pros:
Very nice people to work with
Good bosses and good direction 
Comfortable environment
Working with very smart people too which is appealing
cons:
Nothing really
Given the academic nature of some of the people who work there, they can be a bit socially awkward but this only applies in some places

review_title: Monotonous work, but excellent career potential.
pros: For entry level lab work, they pay significantly better than any of the hospitals and universities in Boston. They offer plenty of learning opportunities and career advancement potential. 3 weeks of paid vacation to start (which doesn't include the mandatory, paid week long christmas break) along with excellent insurance plans.
cons: Sometimes the bureaucracy can be overwhelming and higher level faculty can be intimidating.

pros: Great benefits - can take classes almost for free, access to Harvard's rich resources, working for an organization with an important mission.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy, things move at a glacial pace, hard to get things done, high degree of silos and lack of collaboration between schools/units.

review_title: Great place to do PhD Research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Expert faculty and tremendous resources. Entrepreneurial environment with respect to commercializing research as well as managing one's own project.
cons: Sometimes a lack of guidance can be a problem. Must be a self-starter and able to think creatively.

pros: You get to interact and work with great people doing great things. Benefits are great if you work more than half time.
cons: No benefits for less than half time, and few openings to progress even if you've worked in your position from years. I hear this from other LHT workers a lot.

review_title: An incredible community of faculty and students
job_title: Adjunct Associate Professor in Cambridge, MA
pros: A hub of architecture culture and discourse. Draws an international body of the best students. Vital ties to the rest of the university. Great peer group of faculty.
cons: Vague hiring and promotion policies. Competitive atmosphere among both faculty and students. However these are all the challenges that one should expect at a university of this caliber.

review_title: Harvard is an excellent place to work
pros:
- top-notch benefits
 - smart management
 - good facilities
 - competitive compensation
 - get to work with some of the very best people
 - probably a good thing to have on your resume going forward
cons:
- institutional inertia and red tape
 - a small number of students are inappropriately demanding
 - perhaps too much bureaucratization risks losing sight of academic mission

pros: Many different perspectives, good employment opportunities, never a dull moment. Once you're niched, you'll have a great time. Very important to bury oneself in work, otherwise facing isolation.
cons: No work-life balance. Bureaucratic. Poor community.  Dishonest administration. Undervaluing of undergraduate health, both communally and individually.

pros: Nice to work with smart professors. All the students I met were very driven. Cool to be a part of something big.
cons: You sometimes have to deal with a good amount of bureaucracy. Particularly when it comes to administering exams and whatnot

pros: Access to all resources of Harvard . Flexible timings . Ability to attend all Harvard events and amazing networking opportunities. Good work-life balance.
cons: Position not structured yet. Position lies in a grey area of not a student but not staff too. Job in-security due to project based funding .

review_title: They want everything; you get nothing in return
pros: It is a great environment that you meet some very intelligent people. Has access to state-of-the-art facilities and equipment, good benefits... and this is all you get out of them.
cons:
This review is just from the perspective of someone who started as a postdoc and was promoted to the level of Research Scientist. It probably does not apply to other positions. 

By the name alone it seems like an institution that will open a million doors and will give you many opportunities. Well it is not. That is the elaborate trap that sucks in hundreds of postdocs every year.  As a results we join in and we are called to live in a city that the average rend is 1500 for a studio with a scary of $45,000. And somehow we manage. Our savings (if we have any are exhausted) by the 25th of the month we have no money for food and on top of that we are called to work late nights weekends, holidays, snowstorms and even when the city is in lockdown. And this is doing a conservative life. Imagine this now, but also being naive that you can start a family. Who you think you are? Start a family? Oh no... Absolutely no. I have one. I work as a line-cook to a restaurant to get by. Guess what/ My work there is recognized a lot more. I get paid a more compared to the hours I put. 

And things get worse. Harvard has a series of elaborate schemes to feed the illusion they promote that you are "advancing your career". They tell you that we don't keep postdocs here for more than 3 years because "it is not good for you". Instead the promote you to "Research Associate" to advance your career. What they don't tell you is that you are still a postdoc that will still be overworked and underpaid and you will only get paid 5000 more. Yes this is it folks! PhD 3+ year of postdoctoral experience and you get $50,000. What a job! Who wouldn't want that. Here spend the rest of your life like this. I call it modern day educated "slavery".  We are there because we love what we do. We are willing to pay our dues, but at the end of the day it is coming to doing what we love or living decently.

The PIs are keeping you to help them and there is no interest to advance your career. It is all about them. You get nothing out of it. Well you get 50000. You are mid thirties living with a roommate, no prospect of family and no prospect of promotion.

Harvard Administration does nothing to protect us from this. They willing look the other way and allow this perpetuate. Postdocs are highly trained, results producing machines that are used, literally used, to promote faculty. Went he money runs out you are just out. No interest in what you will do, no care and remorse. It's on you. 

It is the worst place to work in academia. Even if one prospective postdoc reads this and is protected then my mission is done. 

Please don't come to this hell on earth. Protect your rights, your life, your family, your mental health and your career. Please do not come.

job_title: Senior HarvardX Fellow in Cambridge, MA
pros: I loved supporting faculty in experimenting with digital technologies.   The new media afford faculty an opportunity to reach a much wider audience.  I also liked the experimentation with the first HarvardX  MOOCS.  See my resume for an article I co-authored --  Anthropology in and of the MOOC
cons: In many ways, it's revolving door where many colleagues leave after a relatively short time.

review_title: Great benefits/PTO, slim chance of advancement
pros: Access to continuing education, excellent benefits, PTO and decent pay compared to other colleges in the area. Provides stability.
cons: Very few opportunities for advancement unless you know the right people who are willing to help and/or mentor. You get pigeon-holed into the same type of role, difficult to branch out and do something different and worthwhile. No support from managers and senior leaders

pros:
- Benefits
- Perks (such as discounts on local things, and ability to use Harvard athletic facilities)
- If you are support staff, you're automatically part of a union
cons:
- As support staff, you can feel insignificant, especially if you are supporting faculty
- No room to grow; if you want an advancement, though, you can apply internally for a different, better position
- Pay not great

pros: Flexible jobs for term time makes it great to be a student and work at the same time. Management is often good.
cons: Work is often menial, and the nature of the university makes it hard to incite change. Decisions are often made by people not familiar with the jobs.

review_title: Great place to work and collaborate...busy!
pros: Always interesting and stimulating to talks to attend-- most often about topics of great relevance to todays challenges. Students, staff and faculty are more approachable and friendly than you would assume.
cons: A lot is expected from you. There is a culture of always "being busy" or "looking busy" that sometimes I wonder how productive people really are, or how much are they really contributing.

pros: Open environment with smart people and flexible hours. Good amount of exposure across disciplinaries. Great access to resources.
cons: The large, overarching environment is pretty good, but the micro-environment can vary a lot. It can be poorly managed if the PI is not seasoned or experienced in people management.

pros: The leadership and management at this company is truly outstanding. Each person strives to achieve perfection and always has the best interest of the company and their team in mind.
cons: Location is the only down fall to working for this great company. Although the city life is a great addition, getting to and from work each day really can be a burden at times.

review_title: Great community, strong benefits, some dead weight
pros: HGSE is a warm and inclusive community, and most employees are driven by a real desire to do good in the field of education. Harvard also offers above-average salaries and excellent benefits.
cons: The school hesitates to fire people who can't pull their weight, meaning you may need to work around certain employees.

pros: Most satisfying is the intellectual vigor that surrounds this place. Access to almost anything you might need. Hopefully good job opportunities later.
cons: Busy, highly competitive, in big city, and hard to make ends meet at the end of the month with family.

review_title: A valuable experience where I was able to pick up job training.
pros: Very professional attitudes when in the work place.  I felt as if my performance was noted.  If I had stayed on, I feel as if I could have easily transitioned to more roles.
cons: Payroll was not properly integrated, and it took weeks for changes to be made.  Luckily I had other sources of income.

pros: Harvard University has generous benefits, including good vacation and sick day allowances. Working on campus brings along a lot of additional benefits that accompany a major university.
cons: Like many private universities, Harvard is careful to protect its name, reputation, and faculty. While this makes sense at some levels, it also tends to add excessive layers of admin.

pros: Grad school - pretty much the same everywhere. Good stipend rate overall, better than MIT and other Boston area schools. Depends heavily on which group you work in.
cons: Stipend rate is low for Boston cost of living. Increases 3% per year, but Boston area cost of living is growing at ~5-6%. People with egos, professors that don't care about the students, etc.

pros: cutting edge technology, agile methodology, good collaboration, cross functional teams
cons: building was 15 minute walk from the centralized campus, travel to and from meetings could be a challenge. compartmentalized support rather than centralized.

pros: There is a great amount of intellectual curiosity in the office, and managers allow you to be flexible in your work hours as long as meet project deadlines.
cons: At times, the hours and projects can be demanding, which naturally require you to work overttime unofficially.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: Being a graduate student in SEAS at Harvard is great.  HUGE pro: the administration strongly cares about students AND looks out for them.
cons:
I guess I'd say some of the bureaucratic deadlines are negotiable, so that can be frustrating at times, but then that kind of only helps the students, sooooo.

Very weak dental coverage, such that a lot of students just opt out.

pros: Brilliant people. Not money-driven. Good work/life balance for staff.
cons: Lack of progression. It doesn't matter if you are just okay or great at your job; you can be fired, but you won't get a bonus or promotion. There are many silos, so it is easy to become invisible.

job_title: Student Library Assistant (Judaica Division) in Cambridge, MA
pros: If you want to get paid a higher salary than many of the other on-campus work opportunities working with amazing people and a friendly management on really fascinating materials, this is the place for you!
cons: The management can be a little too intense with work and reviews, but that is because the work you do means a lot to them.

review_title: Relatively Good Salary, Fairly Intense Environment
job_title: Ph D Student in Boston, MA
pros: I feel privileged to be a student at Harvard. The resources are outstanding.  Overall, my department is pretty laid back relative to other departments.  People are very friendly and generally give each other lots of respect.
cons: People like to brag about working all the time, even if they don't.

pros: Access to many proprietary resources, Learning and working with some of the best in their fields, Many opportunities for networking and making new connections
cons: In any academic environment the pace is much slower and this takes adjustment. In research showing your worth is not always seen as important and the investigator's time is very limited so you must be proactive in managing your career.

review_title: Many bright people trying to do the best work in a broken environment.
pros: Exciting projects. Fast paced environment with good budgets.
cons: Quite a bit of turnover in the ranks. Management doesn't change often. Sometimes you can be in the dark about reasons for events.

pros: excellent benefits, specifically the ability to take classes for free as well as a number of employee perks such as discounted gym membership at the Harvard gyms, and discounted tickets for such things as museums, movies, parks, etc.
cons: it is academia, so the pay starts out very low

pros: Important work and mission, intelligent and creative peers, excellent benefits and opportunities to collaborate with professional and like-minded peers.
cons: decentralized administration sometimes causes delay in getting things done.

pros: The benefits are amazing (free classes, healthcare, wellness programs, Center for Workplace development, excellent time off), the management/leadership is wonderful and people-focused, inclusivity is promoted, and you have a very healthy work/life balance (nobody really works past 5pm). Job duties are clear and well-defined.
cons: A little too siloed. It's a little challenging to cross-train into different jobs.

pros: Best resources, the most qualified people and the most cutting edge work - combination of all this is happening right here.
cons: High-stress and really competitive environment - be prepared to be stressed about work. Growth rate is slower compared to smaller universities.

pros: The most fun I've ever had at a workplace.  The office staff are extremely nice and always have fun stories to share.  They are efficient and productive, but understand how to have a god time while being so!
cons: Sometimes tasks are tedious (or even unnecessary) due to administrators lacking technical knowledge.

review_title: Excellent atmospher, intellectually stimulating, mecca of research
pros: intellectual crowd, excellent research, good courses, great teachers, nice city to be in. YOu would love it if you want ti have a intelllectually satisfying life.
cons: Too cut-throat atmosphere, grilling teachers. Sometimes it can be really stressful. Lot of hours in the library studying, and still you may feel very behind in studies.

pros: The people are amazing to work with and for...inspiring work with highly intellectual staff, faculty, and students lead to many rewarding years of work.
cons: Being the leader sometimes leads to paralysis via analysis.  The speed of change is also difficult for folks that find success in the speed to implement and change culture with a team of people.

pros: Interesting, energetic campus environment.  Lots of seminars, talks, etc to attend.
cons: Poor pay, schools are run like independent companies.  Not centralized, so hard to find information for other schools or departments.  Many non-contributing employees are promoted and/or transferred rather than dealing with them directly,

pros: Depending on the school and department (Harvard in very decentralized) Harvard can be a terrific place to work. There is alot of opportunity to grow your skill set and seek out other opportunities on campus. Good benefits.
cons: Relatively low pay but this is balanced with work life balance and plenty of PTO.

pros: Usually a relaxed pace of work, unless under the gun. Nice perks: ice cream socials, etc. Generally free to explore tech as you'd like, provided it fit into the general environment.
cons: Some of the people had been there way too long, maybe were a bit too comfortable and/or weird.

pros: low stress, great work life balance, great benefits- must take advantage of the educational benefits in order for this job to have value below director level.
cons: low growth opportunities and low compensation, people stay in their roles for an extremely long time. Great place to work once you hit the director level (retirement job, low stress levels), other than that I would look elsewhere.

pros: A flexible schedule, very engaging environment and very helpful and smart colleagues. You get a lot of job fulfillment.
cons: Really no downsides, except the low pay as a graduate student, plus no dental insurance. Otherwise It is a pretty neat place to be.

review_title: I worked in three different admin roles
pros: Great benefits, generous time off, stimulating work environment. Higher pay than similar admin jobs at other universities. Great work/life balance.
cons: Upward mobility for admin jobs is possible but is a very slow process. Can take years and years. Human resources is generally unhelpful and extremely slow. Lots of bureaucracy in general.

pros: I’ve been able to implement my ideas without much pushback and feel appreciated by my boss and colleagues.
cons: Staff are asked by people who have no idea of the impact  to move offices without much thought given to how it impacts work and morale.

pros: Profound respect for colleagues, the way things are managed and the constant challenge to serve as the gold standard of development.
cons: It will take a while to climb the ladder since most employees are highly ambitious and competitive. There's also politics involved, as with everything, where if you work with the right people daily you'll advance sooner.

pros: It was really fun to be involved working with various people at Harvard and being able to meet so many people
cons: There were many times where there were internal conflicts at the firm and there was little transparency in their decision making process.

review_title: Good work if you can get it
pros: The people you work with are mostly wonderful. Many are positive, collaborative, friendly, and intelligent, and interested in doing good work.
cons: It is a very large institution, and has overlapping offices since it is so decentralized. It seems that this can make it a bit slow-moving in adjusting, in order to make improvements in process or clarifying goals.

pros: some job freedom; ability to work whenever i want. cutting edge research; good food at many of the university events
cons: arrogent professors who work their students to the bone in the hope of getting a noble prize.  it's a sad fantasy they live

review_title: My experience in Harvard has been wonderful.
pros: Stimulating place to work with ample opportunities for learning, collaborating with world class colleagues, and contributing to a better world.
cons: Fundings in many areas are heavily linked to government budget.  With recent impasse in Washington, quite often many good ideas have to be on hold.

pros: It's Harvard, it will look great on your resume.  Decent pay and good benefits, excellent location.
cons: High pressure environment, pretentious people, and Cambridge and the city of Boston in general are insanely expensive.

pros: I met some of the best people, period. CEPR has a great work culture and truly does excellent work in Education.
cons: It's hard to find any cons for CEPR. The only unfortunate thing is that it's hard to find an opening for entree-level positions.

review_title: Dedicated people working toward a common goal -- a better world for everyone.
pros: Good people who'll work with you to help you meet your professional goals. Great benefits. The school works hard to provide a space where all are welcome and safe.
cons: As with many jobs where government funding was present, regs could get overwhelming and confusing. Technical infrastructure could use a boost.

review_title: Good place to sunset your career
pros: can get away with doing little and just coast
cons: can get away with doing little and just coast - this reduces the level of service which people almost always expect from IT.

pros: As a researcher working on interdisciplinary areas, I can easily discuss my research questions with world-class scientists.
cons: My Ph.D. program in computer science requires taking more courses than similar programs in other schools. That can be a good aspect for some students. But for me, that means I need to spend more time on coursework and less time on research.

pros: Awesome benefit package and lots of perks; lovely setting; world renowned institution; rewards are high if you move up within the organization
cons: At times, very emotionally charged atmosphere; politics is rife and prominent; high stakes lead to poor choices from middle management; not much upward movement within departments

review_title: Excellent work environment, world class people and facilities
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros: Great people, work/life balance, flexible work schedules possible, always plenty to do
cons: Adoption of new and good ideas can take a long time; always need to be aware of what is technically and politically possible; compensation below industry norm

review_title: Great place to work, extremely inspiring
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: You are surrounded by so many extraordinarily smart people, you can take Harvard classes for very little money, the time off is that of a university so...great
cons: postdoc salaries aren't that exciting, competitiveness is high and everyone seems to be very fond of themselves

review_title: Teaching fellows have it quite good
pros:
Ample campus resources and space for PhD students to do their work
Full tuition coverage and health insurance for 5 years on campus for PhD students
Hugely stimulating environment and motivated, exceptional students to teach
cons:
Must be enterprising to find resources, help
Still learning how to provide useful alt-ac advice and connections for humanities grad students and teaching fellows

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: High salaries, tons of interesting research going on.
cons: Very little oversight for treatment of postdocs by advisors.  You might have a great lab, you might have a terrible lab.  It very much varies from advisor to advisor.  The administration doesn't much care about your existence.

review_title: Harvard Visual and Environmental Studies Department Library Monitor
pros: Note: This job is only open to Harvard College students; the pay is relatively low (just above minimum wage), but the job requires very little skill, and allows students to do work while doing the job; employer is very kind, as are department members
cons: None that I can think of at the moment

pros: Grad school culture is great here. The graduate student association is really awesome and it is easy to meet people outside your discipline. Cambridge is an awesome city to live as well.
cons: It can get really competitive in some of the labs. Some labs are collaborative though. Sometimes it is really overwhelming to be surround by too many smart people.

review_title: Lots of great colleagues, but a system bogged down in balkanized bureaucracy
pros: Good health benefits through Harvard University health system, many gyms and lots of incidental perks. Lots of brilliant and driven colleagues. Access to one of the world's great library systems.
cons: Lots of entrenched bureaucracy. Tenured faculty have much power, but graduate student fellows and teaching staff have little ability to circumvent.

pros: Fantastic brand attracts brilliant scientists and conferences. Each person that I worked with was at the top of his or her field. Very inspiring.
cons: My salary was low, making quality of life in Boston less than stellar. My bank account wouldn't let me stay longer than two years, but I wish I could have stayed longer.

review_title: I am a graduate student at Harvard University.
pros: Harvard is prestigious and well-known. On the other hand, their programs are large and impersonal. The research is great, of course.
cons: The advising is not great, impersonal. Not investing enough in training students - you really are a cog in a giant machine as a graduate student in the sciences at Harvard.

review_title: Operations Supervisor- Office of Event Scheduling and Support
pros: Super fun job, lots of interaction with students, staff, catering, facilities, etc. It's a nice first step for anybody who's interested in event planning.
cons: Quick employee turnaround. When I was working there, the office was primarily comprised of temporary employees so people were joining the team and leaving within a matter of months

pros: Great Union & great benefits! Harvard really cares about making their employees happy.
cons: Lots of middle management who impede work. This is specific to my department.

review_title: Harvard is a den of vipers with no accountability and no incentives to treat people well
pros: Excellent connections, plenty of resources, door will open for you
cons: HR is non-function, serves the status quo to a massive fault. The university knows every employee is replaceable due to their international brand, and will do everything in their power to make you feel this way.

pros: The people you meet here are incredibly capable and driven to success. Naturally, when you put enough Type-A's together you create a very competitive environment, but this environment can also drive innovation.
cons: The culture of competition can drive some students to feel very disillusioned with the incredible opportunity they have of attending Harvard

review_title: Depends on who you work for
pros: Harvard has amazing benefits - which is why many people stay. My job was grant funded, so I had to leave when the funding ran out.
cons: How happy people are depends on who they work for and who they work with. It is a massive institution with numerous schools - each with its own culture.

review_title: Great place to be a Teaching Fellow
pros: As a TF designing an interactive and engaging course it is a joy to work at Harvard. The students are willing to take a chance and the faculty support staff are terrific as well.
cons: It is highly structured, so sometimes it feels as though things are happening without a well communicated reason or strategy.

job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: We have a good benefit package, great amount of networking. They have several incentives to minorities and as a post doc, they really take you into account.
cons: Lot of work. You depend on your boss. Sometimes, the complains are handle with no privacy. You are expendable.

pros: Best paying job on campus, easy to apply for, schedule your own hours, easy to fit in minimum hours per week, get a raise every consecutive semester you work.
cons: Cleaning bathrooms is not exactly fun, some captains are more strict about cleaning than others which depending on your work style can affect your experience.

pros: Supportive environment with strong work-life balance. Lots of opportunity for growth and development. Many different types of positions to choose from.
cons: Being a non profit entity pay is lower than comparable jobs in the private sector.  That said there are many side perks to being a Harvard employee including discounted memberships to the gyms and museums.

review_title: Pros and Cons like anywhere else
pros: Great benefits and work flexibility. For higher education, pays well. Easy to move within the University.
cons: Growth prospects are not well defined. Most people stay in their positions until retirement, so to move up, you have to jump around.

pros: Incredible people to work with - both the professors you work for and the students you in your class
cons: Many professors are stretched thin and won't do a great job of telling you what they need from you - it helps if you can anticipate their needs without them asking, which can take a bit of practice

pros:
Great benefits at Harvard, specifically the gym membership and the health insurance which includes dental. 
Pay is around what you would expect for a Postdoc.
Connections that you get from working as a Postdoc here are top notch.
cons: Work/Life Balance is like most other top institutions. Heavily skewed towards work. Can be a little unhealthy at times.

review_title: Great place to work, but management needs improvement
job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- GREAT Benefits - lots of PTO
- Tuition reimbursement/Classes are $40
- Respected organization
cons:
- Internal mobility, while discussed frequently, is not embraced by managers. 
- Hard to trust senior management due to favoritism

review_title: Competitive benefits and access to Academe/History/Prestige
pros: Such a rich environment to live and work within at Harvard. So many opportunities for growth and access to cultural events. Very competitive benefits for staff and felt very appreciated by the institution.
cons: Some offices are not progressive thinking or willing to change.

pros:
Great people
Fun work (most of the time)
Focused on learning / professional development
Great benefits (ex. medical, dental, discounts with local merchants)
Flexible work hours (aka nice work / life balance options)
Events showing appreciation to employees at least once a quarter
Casual side of business casual dress
Pretty location (if on main campus)
Great reputation
cons: Slightly lower salary than private industry

review_title: Intern Experience - Public Affairs & Communications Office
job_title: Public Affairs Intern in Cambridge, MA
pros: Having experience at Harvard always looks good on a resume. Mastered Microsoft Excel during my time as an intern. Worked on projects where I was able to serve as the primary researcher.
cons: Not much interaction with coworkers. The work was also pretty dry- was ready to leave the office by 5:00.

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Great health insurance; has decent cohesiveness and culture within cohort compared to other engineering programs at Harvard; good number of Professors who are nice to work with
cons: Flexibility to work with whoever you want has decreased a lot over the years; the move/expansion across the river may impact employees during the move; quite bureaucratic

job_title: Research Fellow/Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Cambridge, MA
pros: If everything works out then Harvard is wonderful on your resume. Some researchers were able to succeed under the demands and pressures of their professors, but very few. Several other postdocs had to leave research as a career because of poor mentoring and career development.
cons: If something does not work out, then Harvard will haunt you for the rest of your career. In the Boston area, Harvard on your resume does not have as much weight as you would think. Everyone in Boston is from MIT or Harvard.

pros: Great academic environment. The faculty's academic level is excellent, specially the most senior staff. Great to be exposed to the latest ideas in the field.
cons: The downside of top academics is a tough competitive environment. For junior faculty, a steep up or out system where few people stay for the long term.

pros:
Harvard has some of the best benefits around - time off, health and retirement, discounts on Boston events, etc.
Generally good people. 
Network is huge, so there are a lot of resources to take advantage of.
cons: HR is incompetent, and there is a lot of competition at Harvard, so it can be a high stress environment.

review_title: Assistant Director of Marketing and Communications, HSPH
pros: Great infrastructure, benefits, time off. Wonderful content. I learned a ton and have numerous different opportunities to stretch my skills.
cons: Significantly more political environment than I had experienced in more traditional journalism roles. Could be slow and bureaucratic.

review_title: Experience is highly dependent on lab and department environment
job_title: Science PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: Access to resources and collaborations that would be almost impossible to find anywhere else . Great science, great people and great mentors can be found here (this is specific for science PhDs).
cons: Some departments and labs contain unpleasant environments. Students can be taken advantage of.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Cambridge, MA
pros: If you land in a terrific teaching team, you will be satisfied with your pay and your work. But it varies drastically from course to course.
cons: -Certain disciplines, like the humanities, pay systematically less than they do for the sciences. No benefits. Not contract.

review_title: Very nice workplace for enrichment learning and culture!
pros: Culture, environment, learning, research prospects are all great for someone who is young and thinking about science or industry futures.
cons: competition, secretiveness are a subtle but major problem. In a city that is so full of biotech companies people worry about having research potentials stolen.

review_title: Great benefits, with complicated political structure.
pros: Harvard has some of the best benefits in Boston, maybe the best at one time, but perhaps not any more. Still very competitive though.
cons: The political system is structured and rigid. Hierarchy rules all in some departments.

review_title: My experience at HU has been good and bad.
job_title: Research Operations Manager in Boston, MA
pros: HU has some really great people to work with. They want to get things accomplished.
cons: HU has some not so good performers, but that will take time to fix.

job_title: Temporary Research Associate in Cambridge, MA
pros: Beautiful campus, great work environment. Specifically for SEAS, a lot of talented scientists and engineers doing some very interesting and life-changing research
cons: SEAS is in a mode of transition right now, very sporadic it terms of consistency of pay and reply from HR

review_title: Access to the top research resource
pros: Great colleagues to work with. Flexibility in choosing projects. A lot of opportunities for interdisciplinary collaborations and translational technology. Great mentorship.
cons: The pay is low compared to industry pay for PhD holders. Long time needed for publication to come up due to the busy schedule of the principal investigators.

pros: Access to cutting-edge researchers in almost all scientific disciplines, great infrastructure, many talented peers, decent fellowship.
cons: Depends on the groups and research areas, but students working in natural sciences often have long hours (~10h/day).

pros: Very busy place with lots of engaging, smart and interesting colleagues. Never worked somewhere with people who stay with a business for decades. Feel very lucky to be here.
cons: Benefits are generous, for sure, but salaries really lag, especially for such an expensive area of the country. High performers are not rewarded appropriately.

pros: Great work environment. A lot to learn and a lot to give back. Opportunities to move forward. Extension School Classes and Program allows you to get a Harvard Degree. Many plusses like working in Harvard Square, Cambridge. Museums, Libraries and health and employment benefits.
cons: Can't think of any.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Boston, MA
pros: Great opportunities to learn about careers outside of academic science
cons: BBS is a large program with many different labs. Talk to the BBS office and make sure you join a good one. Most people that are unhappy about grad school are in a bad lab. Don't put yourself in a bad situation.

review_title: Good place overall, lots of politics, degree commands high market premium
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Plenty of smart people around, competitive environment keeps you fit. Good perks on campus. Salary is good compared to other grad RA jobs in other unis.
cons: The downside is many many big egos, all in the same place and the politics that comes with it all.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: Pursuing a doctorate degree in a specific field, you are able to gain the depth of study expected for a doctorate. There are many opportunities to collaborate in related fields and attend talks or seminars in entirely different fields that are of interest.
cons: Work environment leaned towards competitive as opposed to collaborative.

pros: Rich school. Many seminars/workshops with great scholars. Lots of lunch seminars - you may not pay often for lunch!
cons: Great scholars nearby -  you might be overwhelmed easily. Some bureaucracy - took a month to get a ID card! Benefits are different per faculty/staff/postdoc/temporary. Parking is horrible.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Opportunity to work with the world class faculty,  culturally stimulating environment, opportunity to work with the brightest minds. Best resources are available for doing research. Mission-driven.
cons: Pay is okay, but not sufficient to afford a living too close to the school. Could improve on the health services/ insurance coverage, the Holyoke clinic is pretty much useless.

review_title: Great place to build a career!
pros:
There are many smart people. Therefore, you can easily help each other.
It is very competitive environment.
Culture is flexible in general.
cons:
Does not compensate well as compared to other academia.
Health benefits do not cover many area, although health care teams are very professional.

pros: Supportive environment, flexibility - ease and ability to control your project is dependent upon your advisor. Can select your own advisor and have ample access to support staff.
cons: Work life balance can suffer but it is determined by your own habits. No set schedule for degree completion and can therefore continue for several years

job_title: Junior Web Developer in Cambridge, MA
pros: The academic environment (especially the calendar) gives a lot of flexibility and understanding, and really encourages you to expand your skills as you go.
cons: Many of the customers include Harvard students and faculty, which can be a really mixed bag. They are often brilliant, but many have overinflated egos.

pros:
Ample research money
Prestigious name
Nice location
cons:
Will not be treated with respect or given credit for work if you are a lab technician and adviser will get away with it
Pay is not great
Many

review_title: I did my PhD at Harvard, and had an excellent experience.
pros: The quality of the people you meet is second to none, and the resources that are available to pursue a PhD in the sciences is also second to none.
cons: As with any PhD, the salary is too low. Too many cookies, not enough beer.

job_title: Staff Assistant III in Brockton, MA
pros: Excellent benefits, generous time off, annual raises for union, my supervisor is very flexible with schedule
cons: None come to mind - if I had to commute to Boston that would be a con for me.
