pros: Best research environment and access to the newest technology. Top-notch coworkers and overall friendly workplace. Good benefits. Cambridge is a great place to meet top scientist in all areas.
cons: Long work hours and stressful job as in all academic research.

pros: Being a TA's is an awesome experience to learn and teach. I feel like I learned more from teaching than from when I took the class because of the in depth knowledge needed.
cons: No real cons, it is time consuming and is not for everyone, specially if already stretched  thin in time.

pros:
generous vacation time, including closing at Christmas.
Strong training opportunities for staff
education benefit for employee is very good
cons: As an employer overall, I think Harvard is very good.  I think the "cons" are more on an individual basis.  For example, my office relocated and now my commute is much more difficult.

pros: Great people here, a lot of freedom for research; great equipment, much help from colleagues; good resources; lots of benefit
cons: I found that the salary is a bit low when you have a family to support; sometimes it can take a lot longer to finish.

pros:
Good benefits
Good pay for industry
Flexible work arrangements
403b with defined contributions
Opportunity to take subsidized courses
cons:
Pays well for IT *within higher ed*, but not competitive with industry in general
COLA don't always happen
"35/hr weeks" are more like 50/hrs

review_title: Great university, Great research, Great opportunity
pros:
It is great to be able to go anywhere and have people recognize my university.
Research community here is very vibrant and wide.  People are very smart and nice.
cons: Graduate salaries suck, though, but the future opportunity is very promising.

pros:
great benefits, particularly health coverage, employer-paid retirement, paid time off, and tuition assistance
stimulating, mission driven environment
in general, colleges and higher education are great places to be
cons:
lack of internal communications is a weakness
recent budget and staffing cuts make for a more stressful environment than in the past

pros: The name opens doors going forward
cons: Teaching is clearly not a priority, both in class itself and even guidance from advisors often leaves a lot to be desired.

pros: Great job for full-time Harvard students looking to build research experience on resume and earn pocket money during the semester. Nature of work highly dependent on the professor that you work with.
cons: Level of supervision again, dependent on the professor. Might not always be available because the hot shot professors are busy.

pros: Excellent benefits, independence.  The exact situation may depend on your local environment and people. It may be excellent or not.
cons: Office politics, management layers may not conducive to producing results, since they are possibly working with divergent goals.

pros: Good benefits, opportunity to move around and keep same employer, interesting, lots going on
cons: not the highest salary, workplace culture varies greatly--it's the luck of the draw with supervisors, inconsistent work life balance

pros: Work with some of the smartest people out there on ground breaking research!
cons: Very very high expectations, in some case very impractical! And the researches are paranoid about their research topics, so there is very little or no sharing of information within the same team. And its unpaid, which sucks

pros: Great management, generous faculty, always so much free food, HUCTW has negotiated phenomenal benefits, get to take classes for Master's degree for practically nothing
cons: Very decentralized system, everything takes time to process, lack of structured training for specific roles but great general training through FAS

pros: smart people, prestige, top-notch research facilities
cons: Research is focused on publishing in top three journals and getting grants. It is very competitive in a negative way, encouraging superficial flashy topics over serious long-term projects. Employment is grant-dependent.

pros: Lovely people to work with, great resources and benefits
cons: Little room for growth, no change in salary, negative work environment - Chances are you may work with toxic leads (doctors, professors, etc) that could impact the team or your environment potentially.

pros: Good pay and smart colleagues.
cons: No tenure, no contract beyond 6 years.

review_title: Great Environment Where Abilities Are More Important Than Appearances
pros: inexpensive to take classes, especially at extension school; relaxed atmosphere; abilities valued more than how you dress; generous vacation time
cons: easy to get too comfortable and not try to go for promotions because you like your job and location too much

pros: Job security, benefits, lots of time off, high pay relative to other higher ed and not-for-profit sector employers
cons: Slow progression, lots of bureaucracy, low pay relative to private sector employers

pros: Working for a higher cause, casual work place, flexible schedule, good benefits
cons: Overworked, underpaid and the University is reducing a great benefit plan by becoming more corporate.

pros: You feel value and heard by management. Great collegial environment, great mentors, and friendships that will last a lifetime.
cons: University forces talented staff to work under 17 hours so that they cannot quality for full benefits. Pretty much all of my colleagues in this part time role live in poverty.

pros: The benefits at Harvard are hard to beat, especially the ability to take classes at the Extension School for a very large discount.
cons: Harvard is a very flat organization and there is a lot of duplication of effort in departments.

review_title: Diversity, openness and plenty of opportunities for career growth.
pros: Openness to new perspectives welcome. A perfect fit for someone self driven who is willing to take ownership over his or her own work
cons: Limited resources and occasional lack of firm direction despite high expectations

review_title: Harvard can give you really wonderful colleagues.
pros: You can meet some of the most intelligent, kind, and socially gifted people of your life while working here.
cons: It can be stressful, and there are very high expectations of performance, but not unreasonably so if you are reporting to the right person.

review_title: Great for stability and benefits; not great you are looking to grow professionally
job_title: Staff Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros:
- Good benefits
- Flexibility and work life balance
- Positive co-workers
- Low stress
cons:
- Growth limited. Ability to take on roles in management determined by degree.
- Cost of living raise only.
- Management is change-adverse.

pros: Great place to work if you have small children. The flexibility is there provided that the quality of your work remains excellent.
cons: Depending what department or school you work at there can be a lot of politics. No different than any other corporation or work environment.

review_title: Great place to work at as a student!
job_title: Student Tour Guide in Cambridge, MA
pros: I was a student tour guide at one of Harvard's many museums of science and culture. My supervisor was great, and the working culture was one of positivity and friendliness.
cons: Pay is not that great, but it is definitely a fun environment.

pros: Great brand, excellent colleagues and access to the best research ideas and projects you can find in the world. Amazing!
cons: Demanding, crazy work hours, sometimes too bureaucratic with too much administration involved. Prepare to work on weekends. There is no such thing as a life-work balance. Only work.

pros: Research environment is great, a lot of good scientists to discuss. very rewarding. good benefit in terms of temporary job.
cons: very competitive, it is not a long term job. needs to find another job fairly quick. the weather in boston is pretty bad.

review_title: Nice environment and rich culture. A lot of activities going on. Also Boston is a fun place to live.
pros: Competitive faculty staff. Big library. Rich culture. Benefit is very good.
cons: Work can be stressed, esp. from peer pressure. Rent is high in Boston. Weather unpleasant in winter.

review_title: Worked as a research assistant at Harvard School of Public Health after completing my BA.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Cambridge, MA
pros: Very satisfying work, excellent colleagues, good pay and benefits
cons: Depending on the nature of the work you get assigned to, it can get very lonely (for example, if all you do is literature reviews).

review_title: Great and fine institution of higher learning
job_title: Manager of Network and Linux Systems in Cambridge, MA
pros: Benefits, flexibility and Job security. 35 hour work week. Continued education.
cons: Lack of upward mobility. No rapid growth. Stagnant organization. Can be career suicide.

pros: The university provided a great environment to work in and a very international culture. Great facilities around the campus for sports as well.
cons: The personnel in laboratories rotates quite often, so you have to be comfortable with meeting new people and getting along with new team members.

job_title: Web Site Maintenance in Everett, MA
pros:
Friendly environment, everybody is nice and everybody wants to help you! They love to cooperate! 
An extra advantage is that there are ping-pong tables all over the place to help you have a ''Healthy mind in a healthy body''!
cons: There are only advantages at this job

pros: Somewhat flexible. If you do not care about being challenged, this is a good place. Excellent time off and sick leave policy, and health insurance.
cons: Underemployment. Depending on which group, there seems to be workplace bullying that goes on here

pros: I greatly enjoy the intellectual community and most of my colleagues
cons: Low pay, high cost of living, compensation toxic at times, low support, high pressure to publish and get grants

review_title: Opportunity of a life time to learn
pros:
- Good Advisors to work with 
- Be able to take courses at MIT as well
- Cutting edge work
cons: - Less well known in certain area compared to other school

pros: We set our own hours, primarily student coworkers, flexibility in tasks for different shifts, certain tasks allow homework to be done during down-time, headphones are allowed during shelving shifts
cons: Can get pretty repetitive and boring at times, not the highest paying job on campus

job_title: University Representative: Tour Guide in Cambridge, MA
pros:
access to outstanding academic community
competitive pay rates
opportunities for personal development
on-campus opportunities for current students extensive
cons:
It's actually a pretty awesome workplace... I don't like this section. If I had to think of things wrong with it...
bureaucracy
very quick pace of life can lead to difficulty balancing

pros: There are bright, accomplished scholars to work for, Cambridge is a lovely town, and the work-life balance is great.
cons: Brilliant scholars not always accessible, not a clear path for advancement, not enough to live well on in expensive Cambridge.

pros: Benefits, location, education, work environment
cons: lower pay, working with employees that are not motivated, lack of performance base incentives.

pros: Good pay and nice work environment - liked it there a lot. Friendly colleagues and nice office space, it is hard not to like.
cons: None. I can't think of any, only enjoyed my work there. I wish I could have taken on a full time position.

pros: excellent benefits including healthcare, retirement, and discounted courses at Harvard Extension School
cons: upper management decisions often made without the participation of the larger community

job_title: Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good experience. Full access as a undergraduate student. The professor was very nice to us and the team was really great.
cons: No. Everything is perfect. Good experience. Full access as a undergraduate student. The professor was very nice to us and the team was really great.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros:
-Ability to hire and train your own team
-Solid graduate students to hire 
-Autonomy and flexibility
-Good benefits (including vacation)
cons:
-Not a lot of room for growth
-Don't offer competitive salaries
-Decision making is lackluster
-Antiquated processes

review_title: Okay workplace but management is very hierarchical
job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Cambridge, MA
pros: Benefits are VERY good especially health care.
cons: Management tends to bend over backwards for Deans and higher sneior level administrators but treats the staff assistants and lower tiered staff very poorly.

job_title: Data Scientist in New York, NY
pros: Harvard, working closing with MIT, is simply the best opportunity to become expert at mathematics, statistics, AI, ML, and DS
cons: Long hours and short deadlines, which are par for the course

pros: Benefits, paid week off from Christmas to New Years, and 35 hour work week.
cons: low salary, no opportunities for promotion, over worked, unfair treatment among co-workers from Management, unfair work loads, sexist treatment, and poor communication.

pros: So many lifers - it's impressivre. Great benefits, great training and upward movement possibilities. You make more in higher ed if you're at Harvard.
cons: Because of the economy, there have been layoffs, so most departments are at max capacity.

job_title: Senior HRMS Business Analyst in Cambridge, MA
pros:
Challenging work environment
Intelligent, forward-thinking co-workers
Great sense of community
Flexible work schedules
cons:
Stodgy, difficult to introduce change
Very bureaucratic, all decisions made by consensus (or not made at all)
Definite class system between faculty and staff

review_title: Great environment with lots of opportunities
pros:
- Stimulating environment with access to interesting data and projects
- Ample opportunities to collaborate, take courses, and learn
- Great colleagues and mentors
- Reasonably well compensated and good benefits
cons:
- Lack of job security due to lack of stable funding
- Very competitive environment

pros: Fantastic benefits. Probably the best you can get anywhere. Starting salaries are also pretty high compared to private companies for entry level positions.
cons: Very tough to move up within a department. People that work for harvard tend to stay a very long time in the same position.

pros:
Good pay, intimate relationship with professors.  
Also a good side job to make a lot of money as a student.
cons: your experience really depends on the professor you are working with.  for example i have heard excellent stories and horror stories.

pros: You work at your own pace, with no deadlines to worry about. They are very supportive and care deeply about your welfare.
cons: I am very happy with the Center. It's a pressure-free environment. One's level of productivity is dependent on one's personal goal and motivation.

pros: Flexibility, benefits, vacation time, salary compared to other higher Ed settings, extras that come with working at such a large university
cons: The decentralized environment of the huge university makes things hard to get done; everything is slow moving, and there are lots of politics

review_title: You gain intellectually but suffer financially, big time.
pros: Smartest people around.  Very nice people too.
cons: Pay is horrible.  Some people are workaholics and don't have a life.

pros: It's Harvard. Lots of big names and opportunities for personal connection and growth. Great location. Beautiful. Great people to work with.
cons: No room for professional growth. No pathways for expanding outside of one's role. Archaic systems. Everything takes way too long to get done.

pros: Harvard University offers good pay to its student Teaching Fellows. Highly recommend for undergrads.
cons: Holding a job on campus while keeping up with schoolwork is difficult but nonetheless rewarding.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Great benefits. The allocated vacation time is good.
cons: Postdoctoral Research Fellows salary is very low. Universities like Stanford raise the postdoc salary to accommodate the high cost of living in Palo Alto. Harvard should have enough money to treat their postdocs similarly.

pros: Great perks and benefits. Flexibility. Health care. Job security.
cons: Larger departments are messy and management often seems incapable of completing projects.

review_title: An excellent employer, challenging and interesting work activities, knowledgeable colleagues, and constantly evolving
pros: Independent, critical thinkers can go far by partnering with leadership to advance complex projects
cons: Higharchial nature of academia can take time to get used to

pros: benefits, people, learning a lot
cons: burnout, change-resistant, hierarchical, political

pros: The benefits and training opportunities
cons: The Deans and Administrative Deans are often out of touch with reality.

pros: Student jobs are great, compensation is great, get to work with the management and people much higher up than you right from the beginning
cons: Working while a student is difficult because of time management. Beyond that, I have no complaints and everything is awesome

pros: Great opportunity to gain extensive teaching experience while still having time and support to pursue research (especially during the summer and second year, when your courses are prepped)

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Cambridge, MA
pros: Hub of intellectual activity. Can build collaborations just by being present in the University. The vast majority of faculty is very smart and competent.
cons: Like all graduate programs, the success and failure of your degree is determined by your relationship with your supervisor.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros: You are trusted to do your job without a ton of oversight. Lots of responsibility and are treated like an adult.
cons: Salaries are very low as are yearly increases that are not based on merit.

pros: Tremendous learning environment.  The tuition reimbusrement benefit is great at the Extension School.
cons: Fast paced research feel obligated to work some nights and weekends.

review_title: Summer job; fine but nice place to work
pros: It's a really, really nice place to work with a lot of very interesting place.
cons: Personal experience -- I was just doing a summer job, so not all the work was particularly glorious.  To be expected, however.

review_title: Not much room for growth in the Harvard alumni association
job_title: Staff Assistant III in Cambridge, MA

review_title: overall a great place to work, some departments don't have a great work/life balance
pros: excellent benefits, great working in a higher education environment -- interesting workshops, events with special guests, wonderful colleagues

pros: State of the art facilities, striving for excellence in all elements of education

review_title: Worked in the University Development Office
pros: Great mentorship.  Everyone is competent and works their best.

pros: The best reasons to work are Harvard are the benefits and resources available to employees.

review_title: Fantastic research environment; extremely difficult to get tenure track positions and beyond
pros: The best minds in the world come here. Research facilities and interactions are outstanding.

pros: Great collages and intellektuellt challenging and stimulating work. I have varied tasks and get a lot of responsibility. Flexible hours.

job_title: Staff Assistant Specialist in Cambridge, MA

pros: Worked at a small fundraising office with some incredibly talented fundraising directors. You will see the inner workings of how big buildings are paid for!

review_title: Research Assistant at Harvard Kennedy School

pros:
Close support with course preceptor and heads.
Great people to work with.
Beneficial self development experience to have.
cons: It can be very late shifts, if remote working in another country. But this is accommodated as much as possible with a number of time slots.

pros: I think they treat their employees very well.

review_title: Harvard is a complicated, but great, place to work
pros: Competitive pay, amazing benefits, flexibility in schedule

job_title: Research Fellow, Robotics in Cambridge, MA

Access to amazing minds who were always eager to help out.

Just the standard con of any non-professor academic job. 
Low pay.

pros: It's a professional organization. For a postdoctoral position, the salary is on the high end. There's a lot of opportunity for research.

review_title: Work-life balance, but in an atmosphere with tricky social cues . . .

HR takes the lead in this discriminatory environment with zero accountability at the highest levels of the institution.  Their misconduct is hidden behind the curtain of the venerable Harvard name.

job_title: Harvard College Fellow in Cambridge, MA
pros:
One of the best place to work.
